results.title: The Invisible reef
results.creator_credit: Milan Chvostek and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Through the modern-day magic of micro-photography, viewers are led deep into the mysterious folds of the world’s oldest known eco-system - the coral reef. Here, cameras study how a coral reef is formed and perpetuated by a complex system of recycling that makes use of all available energy and materials. But more then that they find fantasy in a biological wonderland. Narrated by William Whitehead.

results.title: The Invisible planet
results.creator_credit: Mauri Goldberg, National Educational Television and Prism Productions
results.brief_description: This film covers a twenty-four year study of Barnard’s Star, the star nearest to the earth observable from the northern hemisphere, by Doctor Peter Van De Kamp. It also shows the discovery of what is claimed to be the first planet to be found outside our solar system. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: The Invisible net
results.creator_credit: Sarah Vincent, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Sarah Vincent looks at 2008, a year of immense ups and downs, and, in particular, when she was diagnosed with cancer. Rather than dwelling on the treatment and anxiety, Sarah chooses to focus on the amazing support she received from her community of family, friends, the school and neighbours. Through their support, Sarah learned to count her blessings and credits cancer with changing her outlook on life.

results.title: The Invisible Man
results.creator_credit: Jason Blum, Blumhouse Productions, Universal Pictures, Goalpost Pictures, Leigh Whannell, Emily Seresin, Alex Holmes and Kylie du Fresne
results.headline_credit: Australia and United States of America, 2020
results.brief_description: When Cecilia’s abusive ex takes his own life and leaves her his fortune, she suspects his death was a hoax. As a series of coincidences turn lethal, Cecilia works to prove that she is being hunted by someone nobody can see.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

results.title: The Invisible Man
results.brief_description: The Invisible Man is a 1933 American pre-Code science fiction horror film directed by James Whale. Based on H. G. Wells’ 1897 science fiction novel The Invisible Man and produced by Universal Pictures, the film stars Claude Rains, in his first American screen appearance, - WIKI
results.description: Working in Dr. Cranley’s laboratory, scientist Jack Griffin was always given the latitude to conduct some of his own experiments. His sudden departure, however, has Cranley’s daughter Flora worried about him. Griffin has taken a room at the nearby Lion’s Head Inn, hoping to reverse an experiment he conducted on himself that made him invisible. But the experimental drug has also warped his mind, making him aggressive and dangerous. He’s prepared to do whatever it takes to restore his appearance.

results.title: The Invisible link
results.creator_credit: Bern Gandy, Geoffrey Collings, Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A brief explanation of radio broadcasting in Australia. Shows scenes in the Australian Broadcasting Commission’s studios and in the Postmaster-General’s transmission stations through which typical commercial and non-commercial programs are being broadcast. Use of wireless in ships, aeroplanes, police cars and ambulances, including a symphony concert, a radio play and the children’s “Kindergarten of the Air”.

results.title: The Invisible keystone
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
A review of how British constitutional government and British forms of law and order became a valued heritage and a unifying link between members of the Commonwealth. The film moves from one Commonwealth country to another to observe how the democratic formula of government is exercised and kept flexible according to the changing ideas of the time, while the Crown symbolizes a continuity and permanence free of politics. A most significant test of this principle was that of India’s rise to nationhood. Edgar McInnis comments on how institutions inherited from Britain were preserved in the country’s statutes.

results.title: The Invisible handicap: dyslexia
results.brief_description: Introduces basic concepts about the learning disability of dyslexia. Shows candid scenes of dyslexic children and includes the comments of a college engineering student whose first-grade reading ability due to dyslexia has hindered, but not stopped her education.

results.title: The Invisible ghost
results.creator_credit: Joseph Lewis, Sam Katzman, Banner Productions and Monogram Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Bela Lugosi stars as Mr. Charles Kessler in this bizarre, noirish tale of murder and mystery. Every year on the anniversary of his failed marriage, Mr. Kessler conducts dinner with his estranged wife’s ghost within the claustrophobic confines of the house they once shared. The mysterious death of the new housemaid barely creates a disturbance due to the frequency of murders that have occurred in the house in recent months. Mr. Kessler, his daughter Virginia, and Evans the butler struggle to maintain calm as the body count escalates, and the police search for clues to the latest killings. As all the clues begin to add up it seems that the killer may be closer to home than first suspected, and that an evil force reaching beyond the grave may also be to blame. Features some unusual camera work and a fine performance from Lugosi.
